subject: Re: get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: ... When one chooses a particular mapping of CMU symbol to QS letter (namely AA = #32Ah AO = #33Awe ) the CMU dictionary corresponds exactly to:
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:

> The main drawback (as others have
> pointed out) is that the dictionary does not use "On" at all. It uses
> "Ah" for every vowel where either one might be used.
>
>
> >
> > Not that I've tried it, but to approximate this, maybe any capital
> > letter not preceded but terminal punctuation (period, question mark
> > etc) and not starting a block of text can be assumed to be a name.
>
> Yes, this technique would work better. My method right now is more
> simple. Another trick is to find phrases like "President Bush."
>
> Paul
>

When one chooses a particular mapping of CMU symbol to QS letter
(namely "AA" = #32Ah "AO" = #33Awe ) the CMU dictionary corresponds
exactly to:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/typical_us.jpg

It is in fact how I made that chart since CMU does not represent my
personal accent.

If you open the actual CMU text file and look up the lexical set names
PALM (which uses symbol AA), LOT (AA), THOUGHT(AO) and CLOTH (AO) the
CMU merger is quite clear

The CMU is not RP of course but some idealized American and aside from
merging away #34, it also has no #20Whiteweat/Why


Another intractable problem that can *look* like a spelling mistake is
the fault of English itself: the same word is pronounced differently
based on it's grammatical use. In particular the word "use" is
pronounced differently when it is a noun (s ending) and when it is a
verb (z ending). The CMU dictionary provides both entries (you can see
them in the CMU text file with a parenthesis (2) after the second).
But this is useless because figuring out the part of speech of
words from a live feed using python is a tad ambitious.
